etymology.description: Duplication of 木 (“tree”) to indicate multiple trees → forest; semantic: 木 + 木.
etymology.interpretation: Doubling the tree component places two trees together, evoking a grove or woods. Repetition signals plurality, so two trees generalize to a forest; adding a third 木 yields 森 for dense woods.

examples.chinese: 我们走进林中散步(我們走進林中散步)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen zǒu jìn lín zhōng sànbù.
examples.english: We walked into the woods for a stroll.

examples.chinese: 这片树林很安静(這片樹林很安靜)。
市中心高楼林立(市中心高樓林立)。
examples.english: In the city center, high-rises stand in great numbers.
